abstracts.cdata!:
Yemen is vulnerable to periodic
            flooding. In the spring of 1989, heavy rainfall and
            widespread flooding caused devastating damage to houses,
            public infrastructure, flood control and irrigation
            structures, crops, and livestock, with total losses
            estimated at US$161 million representing 13 percent of GDP.
            Wreaked housing left 30,000 people homeless and 6 percent of
            total annual agricultural production was destroyed. In 1996
            floods again caused substantial loss of human lives and
            extensive damage. Losses affected mostly the Marib and
            Shabwa governorates and amounted to 12 percent of GDP.
